questions.text: Eighteen hours after the vaginal delivery of a 2788-g (6-lb 2-oz) newborn, a 22-year-old woman has weakness and numbness of her right foot. She is unable to walk without dragging and shuffling her foot. The delivery was complicated by prolonged labor and the patient had received epidural analgesia. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a high-stepping gait. There is weakness upon right foot dorsiflexion and right ankle eversion. Sensation is decreased over the dorsum of the right foot and the anterolateral aspect of the right lower extremity below the knee. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Compression of the common peroneal nerve

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pregnant women are at an increased risk of lumbar radiculopathy, as an increase in body weight and mechanical stress when bending puts pressure on a pre-existing bulging or herniated disk in the lower back. However, L2–L4 radiculopathy causes weakness of the hip flexors, knee extensors, and ankle dorsiflexors, while this patient only has weakness of ankle dorsiflexion. Furthermore, lumbar radiculopathy manifests with a diminished patellar reflex, whereas this patient has intact reflexes, suggesting a peripheral nerve lesion.

B) INCORRECT:

Epidural anesthesia affects sensory nerve fibers more than motor nerve fibers, effectively providing analgesia without severely impairing a patient's ability to move. Additional doses of anesthesia are required every one to two hours as the body metabolizes the local anesthetic. Given that this patient has not received any additional epidural doses since delivery 18 hours ago, it is highly unlikely that the epidural anesthesia is the cause of her sensory and motor symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Symptoms of postpartum angiopathy include headache, focal deficits, visual disturbances, encephalopathy, and seizure within 1–2 weeks of delivery. It is a rare cause of stroke in the acute postpartum period. However, this patient has focal neurological symptoms in the pattern of a single nerve distribution.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has a high-stepping gait, weakness of foot eversion and dorsiflexion, and decreased sensation in the anterolateral aspect of the leg and dorsum of the foot, which is consistent with common peroneal nerve injury, the most common peripheral nerve lesion of the lower extremity. Because it descends along the lateral side of the popliteal fossa to the head of the fibula, the common peroneal nerve is susceptible to injury during obstetric procedures (See “Obstetric nerve injuries” table). It is likely that this nerve was accidentally compressed during childbirth, especially given the prolonged second stage of labor.

Treatment of peroneal nerve injuries involves removal of the underlying cause (loosening a tight-fitting cast, avoidance of sitting cross-legged). Symptoms are usually self-limited once the cause of the compression is removed. In some cases, corticosteroids may be recommended to reduce swelling and inflammation that is causing compression of the nerve. If the symptoms persist, surgical decompression may be necessary.

E) INCORRECT:

Because of its location in the pelvis under the inguinal ligament, the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve is at risk of injury from compression due to increased intra-abdominal pressure from pregnancy, obesity, or prolonged pushing with hip flexion during labor. Although this patient had multiple risk factors for lateral femoral cutaneous nerve injury, the condition manifests with sensory loss over the lateral thigh on the affected side and no motor deficit.
questions.hint: The semi-Fowler lithotomy position (legs flexed at the hips, abducted, and externally rotated), forceful knee flexion, and use of obstetrical stirrups are common during childbirth and put mothers at risk for a specific nerve lesion.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 26 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department because of frequent contractions. The contractions last 40 seconds each, occur every 2 minutes, and have been increasing in intensity. Her first child was delivered by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of a nonreassuring fetal heart rate. Her current medications include folic acid and a multivitamin. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 126/76 mm Hg. Contractions are felt on the abdomen. There is clear fluid in the vulva and the introitus. The cervix is dilated to 5 cm, 70% effaced, and station of the head is -2. A fetal ultrasound shows polyhydramnios, a median cleft lip, and fused thalami. The corpus callosum, 3rd ventricle, and lateral ventricles are absent. There is a four-chamber heart. The spine shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A cesarean section is conducted when vaginal delivery is not possible or is too risky for the mother and/or the fetus. While this patient's malformations are very unlikely to be compatible with life, they would not hinder a natural birth (in contrast to, e.g., severe hydrocephalus). Cesarean delivery is generally not as safe as vaginal delivery, even after a previous lower uterine segment cesarean delivery, making it less desirable in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Vaginal delivery is desirable in this case because it is generally safer for the mother than cesarean delivery (resulting in fewer postoperative complications and a shorter recovery period), even after a previous lower uterine segment cesarean delivery. However, some women in this situation may insist on cesarean delivery so they can avoid the experience of labor and giving birth to a stillborn fetus. Patients also require thorough counseling about the benefits and risks of vaginal versus cesarean delivery to ensure they are able to provide fully informed consent.

C) INCORRECT:

Tocolysis (e.g., with indomethacin) is used to delay the onset of labor for up to 48 hours so that antenatal corticosteroids can be administered to preterm fetuses. However, tocolysis is contraindicated if cervical dilation is already greater than 4 cm and/or the fetus has lethal congenital abnormalities.

D) INCORRECT:

To induce labor and delivery, misoprostol (a prostaglandin E1 analog) can be administered to induce cervical ripening, dilation, and passing of the fetus. This patient is already in labor and the cervix is becoming wider and more effaced on its own (high Bishop score), making this procedure unnecessary.

E) INCORRECT:

For elective termination of a pregnancy, surgical abortion may be performed (dilation and curettage with vacuum aspiration). This patient is already in labor, however, and will likely deliver on her own very soon. The risks of this procedure outweigh the benefits in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Tocolysis (e.g., with nifedipine) is used to delay the onset of labor for up to 48 hours so that antenatal corticosteroids can be administered to preterm fetuses. However, tocolysis is contraindicated if cervical dilation is already greater than 4 cm and/or the fetus has lethal congenital abnormalities.
questions.hint: This fetus has alobar holoprosencephaly, a rare malformation where the cerebral hemispheres do not divide. This congenital anomaly will very likely lead to stillbirth.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravid woman at 39 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor. Pregnancy was complicated by mild oligohydramnios detected 1 week ago, which was managed with hydration. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows 100% cervical effacement and 10 cm cervical dilation; the vertex is at 0 station. Fetal heart tracing is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An elective cesarean delivery is planned and scheduled before the onset of labor for several reasons, including when vaginal delivery is likely to be complicated (e.g., due to uterine abnormalities, fetal macrosomia), to prevent transmission of infections (e.g., HIV) from the birthing parent to the fetus, and in rare cases, because of patient preference (e.g., strong fear of a painful birth). As this patient presents with active labor and 10 cm cervical dilation, elective cesarean delivery is no longer an option.

B) INCORRECT:

Emergency cesarean delivery is indicated if the parent's and/or baby's life are at risk, e.g., due to suspected placental separation, uterine rupture, severe fetal bradycardia, or fetal acidosis. In a fully dilated patient with variable decelerations, the goal is to first attempt vaginal delivery, especially if other interventions can relieve cord compression. Cesarean delivery should be considered if the decelerations persist and/or fetal distress develops (e.g., heart rate < 110/min) despite conservative measures.

C) INCORRECT:

Reassurance is appropriate when early decelerations or intermittent variable decelerations are observed on fetal heart rate tracings. Early decelerations are gradual decreases in the fetal heart rate that mirror uterine contractions and are caused by fetal head compression, typically indicating a benign response during labor. Intermittent variable decelerations are decelerations that occur in less than 50% of contractions over a 20-minute period and are usually related to temporary umbilical cord compression, which is usually not harmful to the fetus. However, the presence of recurrent variable decelerations, which are decelerations that occur in 50% or more of contractions in a 20-minute period, suggests persistent umbilical cord compression, requiring immediate intervention to prevent further complications.

D) CORRECT:

In patients with suspected umbilical cord compression, intrauterine resuscitation measures should be initiated as soon as possible. Repositioning the birthing parent (e.g., turning to the left or right lateral position or knee-chest position) is a reasonable first step that can relieve cord compression by shifting the baby's position or alleviating pressure from the uterus on the umbilical cord. Administration of an IV fluid bolus (e.g., normal saline or lactated Ringer’s) can further help improve the parent's circulation and fetal perfusion, especially when the parent's dehydration or hypotension may be contributing to cord compression. Supplemental oxygen is not routinely recommended unless the parent is hypoxemic.

E) INCORRECT:

Administration of tocolytics is required in several circumstances, including cervical insufficiency, premature contractions at 24–34 weeks' gestation, and to provide time for adequate intervention if complications arise (e.g., for cesarean delivery). While tocolytics may be indicated in this case, they are not the first step in management.

F) INCORRECT:

Elevation of the fetal head or other presenting body part is a maneuver used to relieve pressure on the umbilical cord in cases of umbilical cord prolapse. This acutely life-threatening condition is diagnosed through vaginal palpation of the umbilical cord and continuous fetal bradycardia seen on cardiotocography. Since this patient has no signs of cord prolapse, elevation of the fetal head is not required.

G) INCORRECT:

Rapid amnioinfusion provides an extra cushion of fluid around the umbilical cord. While this may improve the symptoms suggestive of umbilical cord compression seen here (recurrent variable decelerations on cardiotocography), it is not the first step in management.
questions.hint: Decelerations occurring in ≥ 50% of uterine contractions in a 20-minute period are known as recurrent variable decelerations and suggest umbilical cord compression.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 40 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital 30 minutes after spontaneous rupture of membranes without labor pains. She delivered her first child vaginally at 38 weeks' gestation. Pregnancy was complicated by hypothyroidism. She has no other history of serious illness. Medications include levothyroxine and a multivitamin. Her pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 40-week gestation. Fetal heart tracing is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the cardiotocography findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Recurrent variable decelerations suggest umbilical cord compression. PROM increases the risk of cord prolapse, which should be ruled out via speculum examination as the cause of cord compression. In patients with suspected umbilical cord compression, intrauterine resuscitation measures should be initiated as soon as possible, such as maternal repositioning (to positions that ease compression, e.g., knee-chest or Trendelenburg position) and administration of oxygen and fluids to improve uteroplacental blood flow and fetal oxygenation.

B) INCORRECT:

An overdose of levothyroxine may result in fetal thyrotoxicosis, but this outcome is extremely rare (unless an intentional overdose occurs!) because the requirement of levothyroxine actually increases by up to 50% during pregnancy. Moreover, fetal thyrotoxicosis would manifest with fetal tachycardia (FHR > 160 /min) and features of maternal hyperthyroidism (e.g., maternal tachycardia, palpitations, anxiety).

C) INCORRECT:

Uncorrected maternal hypothyroidism would cause fetal hypothyroidism, which typically causes fetal bradycardia (FHR < 110 /min). Fetal hypothyroidism may result in decreased fetal movements and decreased baseline variability on the nonstress test but is not known to cause decelerations.

D) INCORRECT:

Compression of the fetal head occurs with onset of uterine contractions and typically results in early decelerations, which show a gradual decrease/return to baseline (≥ 30 seconds) and are associated with uterine contractions. This patient has decelerations of variable duration, amplitude, and form that do not coincide with uterine contractions, suggesting variable rather than early decelerations.
Image Description:

The upper blue tracing shows the fetal heart rate (FHR) in beats per minute (bpm) with a baseline of approx. 130 bpm (green dashed line overlay). The FHR baseline lies within the normal range (green shading overlay) and shows moderate variability (~10 bpm; normal range 6–25 bpm).
The lower blue tracing shows the maternal uterine contractions (in mm Hg). The black markings above this tracing show fetal movements (blue shading overlay).
Contractions and decelerations begin and end together (red dashed line overlay), with the peaks of the contractions coinciding with the nadirs of the decelerations (red arrow overlay). The decelerations are gradual, with ≥ 30 s from onset to nadir. These findings are characteristic of early decelerations.

E) INCORRECT:

Uteroplacental insufficiency typically causes late decelerations, defined as a gradual (≥ 30 seconds) decrease/return to the baseline FHR with a nadir that occurs after a uterine contraction's peak. Common causes of uteroplacental insufficiency are preeclampsia, gestational diabetes mellitus, abruptio placentae, maternal hypotension, and/or maternal hypoxia. There is no history suggestive of any of these conditions in this patient.
Image Description:

The upper blue tracing shows the fetal heart rate (FHR) in beats per minute (bpm) with a baseline of approx. 150 bpm (green dashed line overlay). The FHR lies within the normal range (green shading overlay) and shows minimal variability (< 6 bpm; normal range 6–25 bpm).
The lower blue tracing shows the maternal uterine contractions (in mm Hg). The black markings above this tracing show fetal movements (blue shading overlay).
The decelerations begin after the peaks of the uterine contractions (red dashed line overlay). These are gradual, with ≥ 30 s from onset to nadir (red arrow overlay). These findings are characteristic of late decelerations.

F) INCORRECT:

Fetal CNS depression typically results in a sinusoidal pattern of fetal heart rate or a loss of beat to beat variability. Common causes of fetal CNS depression include congenital CNS malformations, severe fetal hypoxia, and certain drugs (e.g., opiates).
Image Description:

20 minute cardiotocogram (CTG) section

Upper blue trace: fetal heart rate in beats per minute (bpm)
Middle trace (black bars; light blue overlay): fetal movement recording
Lower blue trace: maternal contractions in mmHg

The baseline fetal heart rate of 140 bpm (dashed green line overlay) is within the normal range (110-160 bpm; light green overlay). However, the oscillation is smooth and regular, resembling a sinus wave (rather than the spiky and slightly irregular appearance of a normal trace).

Fetal movements are sparse. There are two contractions visible ∼ 10 minutes apart.

This is a highly concerning CTG suggestive of severe fetal anemia or hypoxia.
questions.hint: This patient has premature rupture of membranes (PROM). Cardiotocography shows a baseline fetal heart rate (FHR) of approximately 136/min and recurrent variable decelerations.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 38 weeks' gestation comes to the hospital because of regular, painful contractions that have been increasing in frequency. Her pregnancy has been complicated by gestational diabetes treated with insulin. The cervix is 50% effaced and 4 cm dilated; the vertex is at -1 station. Ultrasonography shows no abnormalities. A tocometer and Doppler fetal heart monitor are placed on the patient's abdomen. Fetal heart tracing is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Intermittent variable decelerations are not associated with worse perinatal outcomes, and therefore intervention is not required at this time. Continued monitoring is warranted to look for the development of recurrent variable decelerations or late decelerations, which can signal impending fetal acidemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Vibroacoustic stimulation can be applied after a nonreactive nonstress test to stimulate the fetus and examine for heart rate accelerations. However, this mother is in labor with contractions causing fetal stimulation and heart rate accelerations already.

C) INCORRECT:

Amnioinfusion can reduce umbilical cord compression by increasing the volume of amniotic fluid, and is one option for recurrent variable decelerations that have not responded to other less invasive intrauterine resuscitation efforts. This fetal heart rate tracing shows only intermittent variable decelerations, which would not warrant intrauterine resuscitation efforts at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

Fetal scalp monitoring can be used to record fetal heart beats when external monitoring provides inadequate readings. However, the external Doppler is sufficiently recording the fetal heart beat, so that an internal monitor is not warranted at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Emergent cesarean section would be indicated for recurrent variable decelerations or recurrent late decelerations that do not respond to initial intrauterine resuscitation efforts. This fetal heart rate tracing only shows intermittent variable decelerations, which does not warrant an emergent cesarean section.

F) INCORRECT:

Tocolytics can be used for uterine tachysystole when fetal heart rate tracings show variable decelerations or late decelerations. Although this fetus is having variable decelerations, there are only 3 contractions every 10 minutes, meaning tocolytics would not be indicated.
questions.hint: This fetal heart rate tracing shows intermittent variable decelerations, which are the most common heart rate tracing abnormality seen during labor.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 41 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor. Pregnancy has been uncomplicated. At the beginning of the second stage of labor, the cervix is 100% effaced and 10 cm dilated; the vertex is at -1 station. Fetal heart tracing is shown. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the fetal heart tracing findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Maternal hypotension (e.g., due to antepartum hemorrhage, neuraxial analgesia/anesthesia) can result in placental insufficiency, and hence, fetal hypoxia. Fetal hypoxia causes late decelerations on CTG and is characterized by the onset, nadir, and recovery of the deceleration occurring after the onset, peak, and end of the uterine contraction. The CTG, in this case, shows early decelerations that are not caused by maternal hypotension.
Image Description:

The upper blue tracing shows the fetal heart rate (FHR) in beats per minute (bpm), with a baseline of approx. 150 bpm (green dashed line overlay). The FHR lies within the normal range (green shading overlay) and shows minimal variability (< 6 bpm; normal range 6–25 bpm). The lower blue tracing shows maternal uterine contractions (in mm Hg).

The decelerations begin after the peaks of the uterine contractions (red dashed line overlay). They are gradual, with ≥ 30 s from onset to nadir (red arrow overlay). These findings are characteristic of late decelerations.

B) INCORRECT:

Placental insufficiency causes fetal hypoxia and metabolic acidosis, and in turn late decelerations on CTG. In late decelerations, the maximum deceleration in fetal heart rate occurs after the peak of the uterine contraction, unlike the findings in this CTG.
Image Description:

The upper blue tracing shows the fetal heart rate (FHR) in beats per minute (bpm), with a baseline of approx. 150 bpm (green dashed line overlay). The FHR lies within the normal range (green shading overlay) and shows minimal variability (< 6 bpm; normal range 6–25 bpm). The lower blue tracing shows maternal uterine contractions (in mm Hg).

The decelerations begin after the peaks of the uterine contractions (red dashed line overlay). They are gradual, with ≥ 30 s from onset to nadir (red arrow overlay). These findings are characteristic of late decelerations.

C) INCORRECT:

Umbilical cord compression, which is more common in patients with oligohydramnios, causes variable decelerations on CTG. Variable decelerations occur independent of uterine contractions and each deceleration varies in onset, depth, and duration. The CTG in this case is characteristic of early decelerations, which are not caused by umbilical cord compression.
Image Description:

The upper blue tracing shows the fetal heart rate (FHR) in beats per minute (bpm), with a baseline of approx. 136 bpm (dashed green line overlay). The FHR baseline lies within the normal range (green shading overlay) and shows moderate variability (∼ 10 bpm; normal range 6–25/minute). The lower blue tracing shows the maternal uterine contractions (in mm Hg).

The three decelerations visible are abrupt, with < 30 s from onset to nadir (red arrow overlay), and vary in their shape and their temporal relation to the uterine contractions (dashed red line overlay). These findings are characteristic of variable decelerations. As the decelerations here occur with ≥ 50% of uterine contractions over a 20-minute time period, they are termed “recurrent variable decelerations.” This pattern is concerning for umbilical cord compression/prolapse. If persistent, it may prompt considering emergency cesarean delivery.

D) INCORRECT:

A decrease in fetal cardiac function/contractility (fetal myocardial depression) can be caused by uncorrected fetal hypoxia and metabolic acidosis (often secondary to placental insufficiency). The resulting inadequate cardiac output worsens fetal hypoxia and is seen as recurrent late decelerations on CTG. The CTG, in this case, shows early decelerations that are not caused by fetal myocardial depression.
Image Description:

The upper blue tracing shows the fetal heart rate (FHR) in beats per minute (bpm), with a baseline of approx. 150 bpm (green dashed line overlay). The FHR lies within the normal range (green shading overlay) and shows minimal variability (< 6 bpm; normal range 6–25 bpm). The lower blue tracing shows maternal uterine contractions (in mm Hg).

The decelerations begin after the peaks of the uterine contractions (red dashed line overlay). They are gradual, with ≥ 30 s from onset to nadir (red arrow overlay). These findings are characteristic of late decelerations.

E) CORRECT:

Compression of the fetal head with each uterine contraction as it descends through the birth canal triggers an autonomic response that decreases the fetal heart rate (FHR). The beginning and end of FHR decelerations correspond with the progression of a contraction, resulting in early decelerations on CTG. Early decelerations are a benign finding and not a sign of fetal distress.
questions.hint: This patient's cardiotocograph (CTG) shows short (< 3 minutes), gradual decelerations with an onset, nadir, and recovery that correspond with the onset, peak, and end of uterine contractions, which is characteristic of early decelerations.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman, gravida 5, para 4, at 41 weeks' gestation is brought to the hospital because of regular uterine contractions that started 2 hours ago. Pregnancy has been complicated by iron deficiency anemia treated with iron supplements. Pelvic examination shows the cervix is 90% effaced and 7-cm dilated; the vertex is at -1 station. Fetal heart tracing is shown. The patient is repositioned, O2 therapy is initiated, and amnioinfusion is done. A repeat assessment after 20 minutes shows a similar cervical status, and no changes in the fetal heart tracing, and less than 5 contractions in a period of 10 minutes. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient is only dilated 7 cm at -1 station, and thus still in the active phase of the first stage of labor. Active pushing should only occur in the second stage of labor, which requires 10-cm cervical dilation. Active pushing at this point could further reduce placental blood flow and worsen fetal hypoxia.

B) INCORRECT:

Maternal repositioning can increase venous return to improve placental blood flow and fetal oxygenation. However, this patient did not respond to maternal repositioning, O2 therapy, or amnioinfusion. Therefore, she is unlikely to respond to additional repositioning, and further attempts at this intervention would delay a life-saving therapy for the fetus.

C) INCORRECT:

Tocolytics can be used as part of intrauterine resuscitation efforts if > 5 contractions happen within 10 minutes. Tocolytics can transiently stop contractions, and potentially improve placental blood flow and fetal oxygenation, which may reduce fetal heart rate tracing abnormalities. However, tocolytics have not been shown to actually improve neonatal outcomes, and this patient shows < 5 contractions every 10 minutes.

D) INCORRECT:

Oxytocin stimulates uterine contractions, which can potentially worsen placental blood flow and fetal hypoxia. Therefore, oxytocin infusions should be stopped, and definitely not be initiated, in the setting of recurrent late decelerations.

E) INCORRECT:

Monitoring without further intervention can be considered in patients whose cardiotocography shows early decelerations. However, recurrent late decelerations indicate potential impending fetal asphyxia and therefore require further management.

F) CORRECT:

This fetal heart rate tracing shows recurrent late decelerations that persist despite intrauterine resuscitation measures, suggesting continued fetal hypoxia. Therefore, emergency cesarean section is warranted to prevent fetal asphyxia and intrauterine death.
questions.hint: This patient has a high-risk pregnancy (advanced age, anemic status) and is in active labor (> 6 cm cervical dilation) with a fetal heart tracing showing recurrent late decelerations that have not improved despite intrauterine resuscitation measures. This infant is at high risk for impending fetal asphyxia.

questions.text: A 27-year-old primigravid woman at 37 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department because of frequent contractions for 4 hours. Her pregnancy has been complicated by hyperemesis gravidarum which subsided in the second trimester. The contractions occur every 10–15 minutes and have been increasing in intensity and duration since onset. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg. Uterine contractions are felt on palpation. Pelvic examination shows clear fluid in the vagina. The cervix is 50% effaced and 3 cm dilated. After 4 hours the cervix is 80% effaced and 6 cm dilated. Pelvic examination is inconclusive for the position of the fetal head. The fetal heart rate is reassuring. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Ultrasonography is the next best step in management for this patient whose clinical findings (regular contractions and increasing cervical effacement and dilation) indicate that she is in active labor with an unknown fetal presentation. Determining the position of the fetus is essential as abnormal fetal positioning (e.g., breech presentation) may require a cesarean delivery. Ultrasound can also detect an abnormally located placenta (e.g., placenta previa), which can also be an indication for cesarean section.

B) INCORRECT:

External cephalic version is a maneuver done in cases of breech presentation in order to maximize the chances of vaginal cephalic delivery. Because this patient presents in active labor with an unknown fetal presentation, external cephalic version is not indicated at this time. In addition, this maneuver is usually done near term but prior to labor. By the time a patient is in labor, external cephalic version is much less likely to succeed and cesarean delivery would be indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Misoprostol can be used for cervical ripening and labor induction. This patient is already in active labor with an appropriately effaced and dilated cervix. There is no indication for misoprostol at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

Oxytocin is used to strengthen uterine contractions when there is a prolonged latent phase of labor. This patient has been in labor for 8 hours. Since this is her first pregnancy, she would have to maintain cervical dilation < 6 cm for over 20 hours before she is considered to be in prolonged latent phase. Oxytocin is not indicated in this patient whose labor and delivery have been progressing steadily so far.

E) INCORRECT:

The Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit maneuver is used in emergent cases for management of a vaginal breech delivery. Breech presentation that cannot be corrected via external cephalic version is generally an indication for cesarean delivery. However, certain maneuvers exist to manage an unavoidable vaginal breech delivery. This maneuver is inappropriate in this patient whose fetal presentation has not been determined.

F) INCORRECT:

The nitrazine test is used for the diagnosis of premature rupture of membranes, which typically presents with significant leakage of vaginal fluid before labor onset. Because this patient has not complained of vaginal fluid leakage and is in active labor, the nitrazine test is not warranted at this time.
questions.hint: This woman has been in labor for 8 hours and is progressing with appropriate cervical dilation and effacement.

questions.text: A 37-year-old primigravid woman at 36 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital 30 minutes after the onset of labor. On arrival, contractions occur every 8–10 minutes. During the last two days, she has noted decreased fetal movements. The pregnancy had been complicated by gestational hypertension. Current medications include labetalol and a pregnancy multivitamin. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 154/96 mm Hg. On pelvic examination, the cervix is 40% effaced and 2 cm dilated; the vertex is at -2 station. The uterus is consistent in size with a 30-week gestation. Ultrasonography shows the fetus in vertex position and a decreased amount of amniotic fluid. A fetal heart tracing is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Umbilical cord prolapse causes a sudden change from a normal CTG trace to either prolonged fetal bradycardia (< 110/min) or recurrent variable decelerations. The change usually occurs after the rupture of membranes, especially in patients with polyhydramnios, when the sudden gush of amniotic fluid can cause the cord to prolapse. However, late decelerations and oligohydramnios are not typical of umbilical cord prolapse.
Image Description:

The upper blue tracing shows the fetal heart rate (FHR) in beats per minute (bpm), with a baseline of approx. 136 bpm (dashed green line overlay). The FHR baseline lies within the normal range (green shading overlay) and shows moderate variability (∼ 10 bpm; normal range 6–25/minute). The lower blue tracing shows the maternal uterine contractions (in mm Hg).

The three decelerations visible are abrupt, with < 30 s from onset to nadir (red arrow overlay), and vary in their shape and their temporal relation to the uterine contractions (dashed red line overlay). These findings are characteristic of variable decelerations. As the decelerations here occur with ≥ 50% of uterine contractions over a 20-minute time period, they are termed “recurrent variable decelerations.” This pattern is concerning for umbilical cord compression/prolapse. If persistent, it may prompt considering emergency cesarean delivery.

B) INCORRECT:

Umbilical cord compression is more common in women with oligohydramnios because of the lack of an amniotic fluid cushion to protect the umbilical cord from being compressed between the fetus and the contracting uterus. However, umbilical cord compression causes recurrent variable decelerations (i.e., decelerations that vary in onset, depth, and duration, and that occur independently of uterine contractions), whereas this patient's CTG is characteristic of late decelerations.
Image Description:

The upper blue tracing shows the fetal heart rate (FHR) in beats per minute (bpm), with a baseline of approx. 136 bpm (dashed green line overlay). The FHR baseline lies within the normal range (green shading overlay) and shows moderate variability (∼ 10 bpm; normal range 6–25/minute). The lower blue tracing shows the maternal uterine contractions (in mm Hg).

The three decelerations visible are abrupt, with < 30 s from onset to nadir (red arrow overlay), and vary in their shape and their temporal relation to the uterine contractions (dashed red line overlay). These findings are characteristic of variable decelerations. As the decelerations here occur with ≥ 50% of uterine contractions over a 20-minute time period, they are termed “recurrent variable decelerations.” This pattern is concerning for umbilical cord compression/prolapse. If persistent, it may prompt considering emergency cesarean delivery.

C) INCORRECT:

Physiological fetal heart rate (FHR) pattern includes a baseline FHR from 110–160/min, with a variability of 6–25/min (baseline variability), accelerations (associated with fetal movements and autonomic responses), and early decelerations (caused by fetal head compression during normal vaginal delivery). The CTG trace in this patient shows late decelerations, which are indicative of fetal hypoxia and metabolic acidosis.
Image Description:

The upper blue tracing shows the fetal heart rate (FHR) in beats per minute (bpm) with a baseline of approx. 135 bpm (green dashed line overlay). The FHR lies within the normal range (green shading overlay) and shows moderate variability (~10 bpm; normal range 6–25 bpm).
The lower blue tracing shows the maternal uterine contractions (in mm Hg). The black markings above this tracing show fetal movements (blue shading overlay).
There are three FHR accelerations (green arrow overlay), which coincide with periods of increased fetal movement.

D) INCORRECT:

Compression of the fetal head with each uterine contraction as it descends through the birth canal triggers an autonomic response that decreases the fetal heart rate. This mirrors the uterine contractions and is termed early decelerations. Early decelerations are a benign finding and not a sign of nonreassuring fetal status. However, the CTG trace in this patient shows late decelerations, which are indicative of fetal hypoxia and metabolic acidosis.
Image Description:

The upper blue tracing shows the fetal heart rate (FHR) in beats per minute (bpm) with a baseline of approx. 130 bpm (green dashed line overlay). The FHR baseline lies within the normal range (green shading overlay) and shows moderate variability (~10 bpm; normal range 6–25 bpm).
The lower blue tracing shows the maternal uterine contractions (in mm Hg). The black markings above this tracing show fetal movements (blue shading overlay).
Contractions and decelerations begin and end together (red dashed line overlay), with the peaks of the contractions coinciding with the nadirs of the decelerations (red arrow overlay). The decelerations are gradual, with ≥ 30 s from onset to nadir. These findings are characteristic of early decelerations.

E) CORRECT:

Placental insufficiency causes oligohydramnios and intrauterine growth restriction. Because the fetoplacental reserve is decreased in placental insufficiency, stressors, such as labor, can cause fetal hypoxia and metabolic acidosis, which are seen as late decelerations, as in this patient. Gestational hypertension is a common cause of uteroplacental insufficiency. Late decelerations are a sign of fetal distress and should be managed with intrauterine resuscitation and immediate delivery of the fetus.

F) INCORRECT:

This patient presents in the first stage of labor as evidenced by the onset of labor pains 30 minutes earlier and cervical dilation of 2 cm. To diagnose an arrest of active phase of labor, the membranes should already be ruptured and the cervix already dilated to ≥ 6 cm. Moreover, the first stage of labor lasts, on average, for 8–12 hours (longer in primigravid women). This patient currently has normal progression of labor.

G) INCORRECT:

Chorioamnionitis manifests with maternal fever, uterine tenderness, fetal tachycardia, purulent and/or foulsmelling amniotic fluid, and maternal leukocytosis. It is usually associated with premature rupture of membranes and protracted labor. Moreover, a CTG in chorioamnionitis typically shows fetal tachycardia (> 160/min), but not late decelerations.
questions.hint: The onset, nadir, and recovery of the decelerations seen in the fetal heart tracing occur after the onset, peak, and end of the uterine contraction. This finding is characteristic of late decelerations.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 38 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital for active labor. The pregnancy was complicated by gestational diabetes and fetal weight is estimated to be at the 90th percentile for gestational age. During delivery, there is an arrest in the second stage of labor, and a vacuum-assisted delivery is performed. Postpartum examination shows a third-degree laceration in the vagina extending into the perineum at the 6 o'clock position. This patient is most likely to experience which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urge incontinence most often results from detrusor muscle hyperactivity. This is a common concern in patients with multiple sclerosis or those with urinary catheters in place. Perineal lacerations, however, are not associated with the development of urge incontinence.

B) INCORRECT:

Formation of a vesicovaginal fistula most commonly occurs after pelvic operations such as hysterectomy, but is not a complication of third-degree perineal lacerations. This woman's laceration extended in the 6 o'clock direction (i.e., away from the bladder), making it less likely to cause a vesicovaginal fistula.
Image Description:

Urogenital fistulas are abnormal connections between the vagina and the urogenital system (e.g., vesicovaginal fistula). Urogenital fistulas can manifest with continuous urinary leakage from the vagina.

C) CORRECT:

Fecal incontinence is a common complication of third-degree perineal lacerations, which extend through the skin, vaginal mucosa, subcutaneous tissues, the external anal sphincter, and, in more severe cases, the internal anal sphincter. Disruption of the anal sphincter puts this patient at risk for this complication. Even with adequate repair at the time of delivery, this patient may still have persistent anorectal concerns (e.g., involuntary leakage of flatus or stool).

Operative delivery (i.e., the use of forceps or vacuum assistance) and fetal macrosomia are risk factors for third-degree perineal tears.
Image Description:

First degree: cutaneous to subcutaneous tissue tear (skin, fourchette, posterior vaginal wall) with no involvement of the perineal muscles

Second degree: first-degree lacerations plus laceration of the perineal muscles without involvement of the anal sphincter

Third degree: second-degree lacerations plus involvement of the external anal sphincter

Fourth degree: third-degree lacerations plus lacerations of the anterior wall of the anal canal or rectum

D) INCORRECT:

Small bowel obstruction is a very rare complication of pregnancy. It is more strongly associated with abdominal surgery and intraabdominal adhesion formation. This woman's perineal laceration would not cause small bowel obstruction.

E) INCORRECT:

Stress incontinence is associated with multiple childbirths and pelvic floor weakness, but it is not a complication of perineal tears. Multiple vaginal deliveries are an important risk factor for postpartum urinary incontinence due to excessive tension on the bladder from the gravid uterus, which can lead to urethral hypermobility.
questions.hint: Pregnancies featuring maternal gestational diabetes and fetal macrosomia pose an increased risk of obstetric complications. A third-degree perineal laceration involves the structures deep into the perineum and muscles.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 33 weeks’ gestation is brought to the emergency department by her husband 1 hour after the onset of painful contractions. The contractions occur once every 20–30 minutes, last 30–40 seconds, and are associated with an increase in fetal movements. She reports that the pain is not getting worse and that the contractions have been consistent in duration. Pregnancy has been uncomplicated and she attended all prenatal appointments. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows clear cervical mucus and a firm uterus consistent in size with a 33-week gestation. The cervix is 0% effaced and undilated; the vertex is at -3 station. The fetal heart rate is reassuring. After 2 hours of monitoring in the emergency department, the character of the contractions and pelvic examination findings remain unchanged. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: No further action is indicated at this time

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Magnesium sulfate is indicated for fetal neuroprotection in patients with preterm labor before 32 weeks' gestation. This woman is at > 32 weeks' gestation and does not meet the criteria for true labor.

B) INCORRECT:

Admission for monitoring and delivery would be indicated in patients with preterm labor at > 34 weeks' gestation. This patient, however, is at 33 weeks' gestation and additionally does not meet the criteria for true labor.

C) CORRECT:

This woman presents with short (< 1 minute) contractions that have remained constant in intensity, frequency, and duration. In addition, her cervix is undilated and the fetal station is -3 (i.e., undescended). These findings remain unchanged after 2 hours of monitoring. This patient most likely has physiologic uterine contractions (i.e., false labor), which tone the uterus in preparation for true labor and help with fetal positioning. These contractions resolve spontaneously and do not require any treatment. Patients should be reassured, advised to change positions (e.g., walk around), and discharged after a pelvic examination.

True labor contractions are regular uterine contractions that increase in intensity, duration, and frequency and cause cervical changes (e.g., effacement, dilation) as well as descent of the fetal presenting part. True labor with an onset before 37 weeks of gestation (preterm labor) requires further management. In patients with true preterm labor at < 34 weeks' gestation, tocolysis is indicated for up to 48 hours to enable the administration and efficacy of antenatal corticosteroids (which induce fetal lung maturity). In patients at > 34 weeks' gestation, the risks of delay outweigh the risks of preterm birth, and admission for monitoring and delivery is indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Betamethasone is used to induce fetal lung maturity prior to delivery and is indicated in patients at < 34 weeks' who are in preterm labor. Although this woman is at 33 weeks' gestation, she does not meet the criteria for true labor.

E) INCORRECT:

Nifedipine is the first-line tocolytic agent in patients with preterm labor between 32 and 34 weeks of gestational age. This woman is at 33 weeks' gestation, but she does not meet the criteria for true labor.

F) INCORRECT:

Oxytocin is indicated to induce or augment labor in patients with favorable cervix findings (i.e., effaced and dilated) who meet the indications for labor induction (e.g., postterm pregnancy, preterm premature rupture of membranes after 34 weeks of gestational age, premature rupture of membranes at term, preeclampsia). This woman's cervix is undilated and 0% effaced, and there is no indication for inducing her at this time.
questions.hint: Consider the diagnostic criteria of labor contractions, which include the nature of uterine contractions, cervical changes, and descent of fetal presenting part.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 37 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were uncomplicated. She has had occasional tiredness and frequent urination throughout her pregnancy but has otherwise been well. She has attended all scheduled prenatal visits. Her weight gain has been normal. She is in a monogamous relationship with a male partner who is the father. Current medications include micronutrient supplements. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 110/82 mm Hg. Examination shows minimal bilateral edema below the knees. The uterus is consistent in size with a 35-week gestation. Transabdominal ultrasound shows an intrauterine pregnancy in a longitudinal lie with breech presentation; fetal cardiac activity is normal. The physician explains the complications associated with breech delivery and recommends an external cephalic version. The patient refuses and states that she would like to attempt a vaginal delivery at home. In addition to acknowledging the patient's choice and exploring the reasons for her choice, which of the following statements by the physician is most appropriate?

choices.text: "A home birth with assistance from a certified midwife certainly has a few advantages. I would like to contact your midwife so that I can discuss your care prior to delivery."
"A home birth increases the risk of harm to your baby. You must discuss this matter with your partner and obtain his consent before choosing home birth."

"The hospital is the safest environment for delivery. Although we are equipped to deal with any potential complication, the risk of medical intervention during a hospital delivery is actually lower when compared to home birth."
"A home birth is generally not recommended. It concerns me that, if a complication occurs, the delay in transfer to the hospital would result in severe harm to you or your baby."
"You and your baby are at risk of developing serious complications during delivery, which cannot be managed at home. I strongly recommend that you choose to come to the hospital."

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although home births have certain benefits (e.g., lower risk of interventions, familiar environment) in low-risk pregnancies and close communication between the midwife and physician (i.e., parallel prenatal care) can be helpful, this patient has an absolute contraindication to planned home birth.

B) INCORRECT:

Although it is advisable to involve partners in the decision-making process, pregnant women and their care providers are the primary decision-makers. Neither the partner's agreement nor consent is required.

C) INCORRECT:

This statement is not true, since hospital deliveries are associated with a higher risk of medical interventions when compared to planned home birth. One reason for this association might be that women who decide on planned home deliveries are often multiparous and have fewer risk factors.

D) INCORRECT:

This statement is not true, since home births can be considered under certain circumstances (e.g., in a multiparous woman without preexisting medical or obstetric conditions, and a singleton cephalic fetus between 37 and 41 weeks' gestation, with the assistance of a certified midwife). Moreover, while home births can result in delays in care if transfer to a hospital is necessary, a potential delay is not the most appropriate reason for not recommending a home birth in this scenario.

E) CORRECT:

Planned home birth is associated with a decreased risk of maternal interventions (e.g., induction of labor) but a higher risk of perinatal death and neurological complications (e.g., neonatal seizures). Therefore, it is crucial to carefully select appropriate candidates. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) considers fetal malpresentation (e.g., breech presentation), multiple gestations, and previous cesarean deliveries to be absolute contraindications for planned home births. This statement by the physician points out the dangers of home delivery given the patient's risk factors and clearly states that it is not advisable in this situation.

When there is only one appropriate course of action, as seen here, and the patient does not agree, physicians should apply the principle of directive counseling, meaning that they should take an active role in the decision-making process by offering guidance and recommendations based on their expert clinical judgment. If multiple management options exist, each with its own benefits and risks, the principle of shared decision-making should be employed.
questions.hint: The physician must apply the principle of directive counseling in this scenario.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 40 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor. Rupture of membranes occurred two hours ago and she has been having regular contractions. Her pregnancy has been complicated by gestational diabetes treated with insulin during the third trimester. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 98 kg (216 lb); BMI is 37 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. The cervix is 8 cm dilated and 80% effaced; the vertex is at -2 station. External electronic fetal monitoring with Doppler ultrasound is attempted but the physician is not able to obtain a fetal heart tracing. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Repositioning and O2 administration are the most appropriate initial steps of intrauterine resuscitation in the case of fetal distress. It is unknown whether this fetus is in distress because external fetal monitoring failed to obtain a fetal heart tracing, so a different intervention is required at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

Operative vaginal delivery is indicated for the management of fetal distress unresponsive to intrauterine resuscitation. It is unknown whether this fetus is in distress because external fetal monitoring failed to obtain a fetal heart tracing. Even if fetal distress was confirmed, intrauterine resuscitation would still be attempted first. Finally, operative vaginal delivery can only be performed if the cervix is fully dilated and the head engaged (i.e., at least at station 0), which is not the case here.

C) CORRECT:

Fetal scalp electrode monitoring (FSE monitoring) is an invasive (or internal) form of intrapartum fetal heart rate (FHR) monitoring that is typically used in patients whose external FHR monitoring poses technical difficulties (e.g., patients with polyhydramnios, uterine leiomyomas, multiple gestation, and/or obesity). FSE monitoring is only performed in patients whose membranes have already ruptured, either spontaneously or via amniotomy. Contraindications for the procedure include active maternal infections (e.g., genital herpes, HIV) and uncertain fetal presentation.

D) INCORRECT:

An emergency cesarean section is indicated for the management of fetal distress unresponsive to intrauterine resuscitation. However, it is unknown whether this fetus is in distress because external fetal monitoring failed to obtain a fetal heart tracing. Even if fetal distress was confirmed, intrauterine resuscitation should still be attempted first.

E) INCORRECT:

Amnioinfusion with saline is the most appropriate next step of management in cases of fetal distress unresponsive to initial intrauterine resuscitation measures. It is unknown whether this fetus is in distress because external fetal monitoring failed to obtain a fetal heart tracing. Even if fetal distress was confirmed, other intrauterine resuscitation measures should be attempted first.
questions.hint: This patient's obesity is the most likely reason why external fetal heart monitoring with Doppler ultrasound failed to obtain a heart tracing.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of involuntary loss of feces and flatus. Moderate amounts of stool leakage occur multiple times a week, preceded by fecal urgency. She has regular, formed bowel movements intermittently. She has a 10-year-old son who was delivered vaginally. She has chronic constipation, sciatica, and a 15-year history of type 1 diabetes mellitus. Her medications include insulin and sorbitol. Examination shows absent anal folds on the perineal side of the anus and one external hemorrhoid at the 5-o'clock position; the anal sphincter tone is decreased. There is a small amount of stool in the rectal vault. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

External hemorrhoids may result in incomplete closure of the anal sphincter due to prolabation of the hemorrhoids in the anal canal and can cause incomplete anal closure with consequent fecal incontinence. However, the absence of anal folds is consistent with anal sphincter injury, which is unlikely to have been caused by external hemorrhoids.

B) INCORRECT:

Long-standing diabetes mellitus (DM) can cause autonomic diabetic neuropathy, which may result in a decrease in anal sphincter sensitivity with consequent fecal and flatus incontinence. Patients with diabetic neuropathy can also present with associated bowel changes (e.g., constipation); however, in autonomic neuropathy, concurrent signs of peripheral neuropathy (e.g., distal symmetrical sensory loss) are also expected.

C) CORRECT:

Obstetric anal sphincter injury (OASI) is one of the most common causes of fecal incontinence in women. OASI occurs as a result of perineal lacerations that involve the anal sphincter complex (i.e., third and fourth-degree lacerations), leading to a decreased anal sphincter tone. Risk factors for this condition include prolonged labor, operative vaginal delivery, fetal macrosomia, and midline episiotomy. Most individuals with OASI develop symptoms of anal insufficiency (e.g., fecal incontinence) weeks after delivery. Anal sphincter injuries that are not immediately apparent after delivery are unable to receive adequate repair. In these women, symptoms may only first manifest several years after delivery (delayed OASI) when the supporting pelvic floor starts to weaken. The absence of perianal folds in the perianal region (dovetail sign) is characteristic of delayed OASI. The diagnosis of OASI is typically confirmed by endoanal ultrasound.

D) INCORRECT:

Sciatic nerve injury typically results in sciatica. However, this patient additionally presents with decreased anal sphincter tone and fecal incontinence. The anal sphincter is primarily innervated by the pudendal nerve rather than the sciatic nerve.

E) INCORRECT:

Chronic constipation is a common cause of overflow fecal incontinence, which can manifest with involuntary loss of feces and flatus. However, the absence of anal folds is consistent with anal sphincter injury, which is unlikely to have resulted from chronic constipation alone. Moreover, this patient's small amount of stool in the rectal vault is inconsistent with fecal overflow incontinence.
questions.hint: An endoanal ultrasound in this patient would show a disrupted anal sphincter complex.

questions.text: A 34-year-old pregnant woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 38 weeks' gestation is admitted to the labor and delivery unit. She reports vaginal bleeding with mucus for the past few hours. The patient has received regular prenatal care. Her blood group is Rh-negative, and the baby's blood group is Rh-positive. A test for group B streptococcus performed at 36 weeks' gestation was negative. She has a history of hypertension and is currently taking antihypertensive medication. Speculum examination shows moderate mucoid vaginal bleeding. The cervix is 5 cm dilated and 80% effaced. Fetal heart rate is 132/min, and tracing is regular with some early decelerations and no accelerations; heart rate variability is within normal limits. Maternal temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. The patient's contractions are regular and occur every 5 minutes with increasing intensity. One hour later, a repeat speculum examination shows the cervix to be 6 cm dilated and 90% effaced. Fetal and maternal heart rates remain within normal limits, and there are no changes in fetal heart tracing. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Biophysical profile to assess fetal well-being

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anti-D immunoglobulin (RhoGAM) is given to unsensitized Rh-negative birthing parents at 28 weeks' gestation and again within 72 hours after delivery if the newborn is Rh-positive, to prevent future sensitization. Since this patient has received routine prenatal care, she was most likely given prophylaxis at 28 weeks and does not require additional immunoglobulin at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

Intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis is indicated for patients with confirmed or unknown group B streptococcus (GBS) colonization in their current pregnancy and for those with a history of early-onset GBS infection in a previous newborn. This is the patient's first pregnancy, and GBS screening was negative. GBS prophylaxis is not indicated.

C) CORRECT:

As this patient is currently in the active phase of labor and there are no signs of complications (normal maternal and fetal vital signs, normal fetal heart tracing), reassurance and continuous monitoring are the most appropriate next steps in management. The presence of moderate mucoid vaginal bleeding, regular contractions, and normal fetal and maternal vital signs indicate normal progression of labor. The patient’s mucoid vaginal bleeding is consistent with bloody show, which is the release of a small amount of bloody mucus from the vagina and is a common occurrence during the active phase of labor. Bloody show indicates that the cervix is starting to dilate and that the baby is moving down into the pelvis. Providing reassurance and continuously monitoring the patient, the amount and color of the bloody show, and fetal heart rate for any changes will allow for early detection and management of any potential complications.

D) INCORRECT:

Cesarean delivery during the active phase of labor is typically only indicated if there are features of fetal distress, such as severe decelerations or bradycardia, or maternal or fetal complications, such as placenta previa or vasa previa. In the absence of these indications, emergency cesarean delivery is not appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

A biophysical profile is generally performed antepartum, not intrapartum, to evaluate fetal well-being. This patient is in the active phase of labor and, therefore, obtaining a biophysical profile would not be appropriate.
questions.hint: This patient presents with intrapartum bleeding. In patients with intrapartum bleeding, it is important to assess both maternal and fetal hemodynamic stability and evaluate the progression of labor to differentiate between a benign cause and a more serious cause.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old gravida 4, para 3 woman is in labor after spontaneous rupture of membranes at 39 weeks' gestation. She has had three prior uncomplicated vaginal deliveries, with the largest infant being approximately 8 pounds. An epidural is placed, and the patient is comfortable. She progresses to 8 cm dilation, 100% effacement, and –1 station. One hour later, despite contractions every 3 minutes, her cervical findings are unchanged.
There is a triangle-shaped fontanelle posteriorly and a diamond-shaped fontanelle anteriorly. The baseline fetal heart rate is 140 beats per minute. There are accelerations and no decelerations.
What is the most appropriate next step in this patient's care?

choices.text: Placement of the patient in a hands-and-knees position

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Manual rotation has no proven efficacy in reducing persistent fetal OP position and, like operative rotation, should not be attempted with an incompletely dilated cervix.

B) CORRECT:

At the time of delivery, approximately 5% of fetuses are in an occiput posterior (OP) position, meaning that the anterior (diamond-shaped) fontanelle is anterior and the posterior (triangular-shaped) fontanelle is posterior. Persistent OP position is associated with labor abnormalities, maternal complications, and neonatal complications (such as birth trauma and neonatal acidosis).

Expectant management of OP position is appropriate in patients who have favorable clinical pelvimetry, a tested pelvis, and a fetus with a reassuring heart rate. Many patients with a fetal OP position in the first stage of labor will convert to an occiput anterior position spontaneously. Among women with persistent fetal OP, multiparous women are more likely to achieve spontaneous vaginal delivery than nulliparous women.

Key learning point: The most appropriate next step for a woman in labor at term with favorable clinical pelvimetry whose fetus is in the occiput posterior position with a reassuring heart rate is expectant management.

C) INCORRECT:

OP position alone is not an indication for cesarean section because many fetuses may spontaneously rotate.

D) INCORRECT:

No prospective data indicate that maternal repositioning (such as changing to a hands-and-knees position) affects fetal position.

E) INCORRECT:

Operative rotation with forceps should not be attempted with an incompletely dilated cervix because of the risk of trauma to the cervix.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old primigravida woman with persistent breech presentation is seen at 38 weeks’ gestation. She has been on antiretroviral therapy for HIV infection since before her pregnancy and has had an undetectable viral load (<20 copies/mL) throughout the pregnancy; her CD4 count is 550 cells per mm3 (reference range, 400–1600).
The results of fetal monitoring are reassuring, and the fundal height is appropriate for gestational age. A recent ultrasound revealed a normal amniotic fluid index for gestational age, a normal fetal anatomic survey, and a healthy-appearing placenta that does not reach the cervical os.
What is the most appropriate next step in care for this patient?

choices.text: Plan for elective cesarean section at 39 weeks’ gestation

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Breech position occurs when the buttocks of the fetus are adjacent to the birth canal. It is a common fetal position in early pregnancy, but the prevalence decreases with gestational age — from about 22% before 28 weeks' gestation to about 4% at term. Fetuses that are in a breech position at 35 weeks' gestation are unlikely to change without intervention.

Although fetuses in breech position can be delivered vaginally or by cesarean section, both of these approaches risk higher morbidity and mortality than a cephalic vaginal delivery. Thus, external cephalic version (ECV) is recommended to change the lie of the fetus before term; the success rate of this procedure ranges from approximately 35% to 85%.

Clinical guidelines are consistent in recommending ECV and in listing oligohydramnios (amniotic fluid index <5 cm or deepest vertical pocket of fluid <2 cm) as a contraindication to the procedure. However, they vary substantially with respect to other contraindications. According to expert consensus, placenta previa, nonreassuring results on fetal monitoring, hyperextended fetal head, multifetal gestation, and significant fetal or uterine anomalies are contraindications to ECV. Impaired fetal growth, maternal hypertension, and obesity are relative contraindications.

HIV infection is not a contraindication to ECV, and the procedure is not known to increase the risk for perinatal viral transmission.

Given that ECV is successful in many cases and appears to be associated with improved outcomes, it is recommended over observation in women who are suitable for the procedure. ECV is typically performed by a specialist obstetrician.

Key learning point: The most appropriate management for a fetus in the breech position at 38 weeks’ gestation is external cephalic version.

B) INCORRECT:

Although fetuses in breech position can be delivered vaginally or by cesarean section, both of these approaches risk higher morbidity and mortality than a cephalic vaginal delivery. Thus, external cephalic version (ECV) is recommended to change the lie of the fetus before term; the success rate of this procedure ranges from approximately 35% to 85%.

Elective cesarean section without an attempt at ECV is not indicated because it confers higher risks for morbidity and mortality than a cephalic vaginal delivery does. For a patient with well-controlled HIV infection on antiretroviral therapy, vaginal delivery is always preferable if possible.

C) INCORRECT:

Supplemental progesterone therapy can be used in selected women at high risk for preterm labor, but it has no role in preventing or changing breech presentation.

D) INCORRECT:

Amnioinfusion is not appropriate because it involves artificially rupturing membranes to place an intrauterine pressure catheter and infuse the saline.

E) INCORRECT:

Breech position occurs when the buttocks of the fetus are adjacent to the birth canal. It is a common fetal position in early pregnancy, but the prevalence decreases with gestational age — from about 22% before 28 weeks' gestation to about 4% at term. Fetuses that are in a breech position at 35 weeks' gestation are unlikely to change without intervention.

Given that ECV is successful in many cases and appears to be associated with improved outcomes, it is recommended over observation in women who are suitable for the procedure.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 40 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital 30 minutes after spontaneous rupture of membranes without labor pains. She delivered her first child vaginally at 38 weeks' gestation. Pregnancy was complicated by hypothyroidism. She has no other history of serious illness. Medications include levothyroxine and a multivitamin. Her pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 40-week gestation. Fetal heart tracing shows recurrent variable decelerations. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the cardiotocography findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Recurrent variable decelerations suggest umbilical cord compression. PROM increases the risk of cord prolapse, which should be ruled out via speculum examination as the cause of cord compression. In patients with suspected umbilical cord compression, intrauterine resuscitation measures should be initiated as soon as possible, such as maternal repositioning (to positions that ease compression, e.g., knee-chest or Trendelenburg position) and administration of oxygen and fluids to improve uteroplacental blood flow and fetal oxygenation.
Image Description:

The upper blue tracing shows the fetal heart rate (FHR) in beats per minute (bpm), with a baseline of approx. 136 bpm (dashed green line overlay). The FHR baseline lies within the normal range (green shading overlay) and shows moderate variability (∼ 10 bpm; normal range 6–25/minute). The lower blue tracing shows the maternal uterine contractions (in mm Hg).

The three decelerations visible are abrupt, with < 30 s from onset to nadir (red arrow overlay), and vary in their shape and their temporal relation to the uterine contractions (dashed red line overlay). These findings are characteristic of variable decelerations. As the decelerations here occur with ≥ 50% of uterine contractions over a 20-minute time period, they are termed “recurrent variable decelerations.” This pattern is concerning for umbilical cord compression/prolapse. If persistent, it may prompt considering emergency cesarean delivery.

B) INCORRECT:

An overdose of levothyroxine may result in fetal thyrotoxicosis, but this outcome is extremely rare (unless an intentional overdose occurs!) because the requirement of levothyroxine actually increases by up to 50% during pregnancy. Moreover, fetal thyrotoxicosis would manifest with fetal tachycardia (FHR > 160 /min) and features of maternal hyperthyroidism (e.g., maternal tachycardia, palpitations, anxiety).

C) INCORRECT:

Uncorrected maternal hypothyroidism would cause fetal hypothyroidism, which typically causes fetal bradycardia (FHR < 110 /min). Fetal hypothyroidism may result in decreased fetal movements and decreased baseline variability on the nonstress test but is not known to cause decelerations.

D) INCORRECT:

Compression of the fetal head occurs with onset of uterine contractions and typically results in early decelerations, which show a gradual decrease/return to baseline (≥ 30 seconds) and are associated with uterine contractions. This patient has decelerations of variable duration, amplitude, and form that do not coincide with uterine contractions, suggesting variable rather than early decelerations.
Image Description:

The upper blue tracing shows the fetal heart rate (FHR) in beats per minute (bpm) with a baseline of approx. 130 bpm (green dashed line overlay). The FHR baseline lies within the normal range (green shading overlay) and shows moderate variability (~10 bpm; normal range 6–25 bpm).
The lower blue tracing shows the maternal uterine contractions (in mm Hg). The black markings above this tracing show fetal movements (blue shading overlay).
Contractions and decelerations begin and end together (red dashed line overlay), with the peaks of the contractions coinciding with the nadirs of the decelerations (red arrow overlay). The decelerations are gradual, with ≥ 30 s from onset to nadir. These findings are characteristic of early decelerations.

E) INCORRECT:

Uteroplacental insufficiency typically causes late decelerations, defined as a gradual (≥ 30 seconds) decrease/return to the baseline FHR with a nadir that occurs after a uterine contraction's peak. Common causes of uteroplacental insufficiency are preeclampsia, gestational diabetes mellitus, abruptio placentae, maternal hypotension, and/or maternal hypoxia. There is no history suggestive of any of these conditions in this patient.
Image Description:

The upper blue tracing shows the fetal heart rate (FHR) in beats per minute (bpm) with a baseline of approx. 150 bpm (green dashed line overlay). The FHR lies within the normal range (green shading overlay) and shows minimal variability (< 6 bpm; normal range 6–25 bpm).
The lower blue tracing shows the maternal uterine contractions (in mm Hg). The black markings above this tracing show fetal movements (blue shading overlay).
The decelerations begin after the peaks of the uterine contractions (red dashed line overlay). These are gradual, with ≥ 30 s from onset to nadir (red arrow overlay). These findings are characteristic of late decelerations.
questions.hint: Placing the mother in Trendelenburg position may help this condition to resolve.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman, gravida 5, para 4, at 41 weeks' gestation is brought to the hospital because of regular uterine contractions that started 2 hours ago. Pelvic examination shows the cervix is 90% effaced and 7-cm dilated; the vertex is at -1 station. Fetal heart tracing shows recurrent late decelerations. The patient is repositioned, O2 therapy is initiated, and amnioinfusion is done. A repeat assessment after 20 minutes shows a similar cervical status, and no changes in the fetal heart tracing, and less than 5 contractions in a period of 10 minutes. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient is only dilated 7 cm at -1 station, and thus still in the active phase of the first stage of labor. Active pushing should only occur in the second stage of labor, which requires 10-cm cervical dilation. Active pushing at this point could further reduce placental blood flow and worsen fetal hypoxia.

B) INCORRECT:

Tocolytics can be used as part of intrauterine resuscitation efforts if > 5 contractions happen within 10 minutes. Tocolytics can transiently stop contractions, and potentially improve placental blood flow and fetal oxygenation, which may reduce fetal heart rate tracing abnormalities. However, tocolytics have not been shown to actually improve neonatal outcomes, and this patient shows < 5 contractions every 10 minutes.

C) INCORRECT:

Oxytocin stimulates uterine contractions, which can potentially worsen placental blood flow and fetal hypoxia. Therefore, oxytocin infusions should be stopped, and definitely not be initiated, in the setting of recurrent late decelerations.

D) INCORRECT:

Monitoring without further intervention can be considered in patients whose cardiotocography shows early decelerations. However, recurrent late decelerations indicate potential impending fetal asphyxia and therefore require further management.

E) CORRECT:

This fetal heart rate tracing shows recurrent late decelerations that persist despite intrauterine resuscitation measures, suggesting continued fetal hypoxia. Therefore, emergency cesarean section is warranted to prevent fetal asphyxia and intrauterine death.
Image Description:

The upper blue tracing shows the fetal heart rate (FHR) in beats per minute (bpm), with a baseline of approx. 150 bpm (green dashed line overlay). The FHR lies within the normal range (green shading overlay) and shows minimal variability (< 6 bpm; normal range 6–25 bpm). The lower blue tracing shows maternal uterine contractions (in mm Hg).

The decelerations begin after the peaks of the uterine contractions (red dashed line overlay). They are gradual, with ≥ 30 s from onset to nadir (red arrow overlay). These findings are characteristic of late decelerations.
questions.hint: This patient has a high-risk pregnancy (advanced age, anemic status) and is in active labor (> 6 cm cervical dilation) with a fetal heart tracing showing recurrent late decelerations that have not improved despite intrauterine resuscitation measures. This infant is at high risk for impending fetal asphyxia.

questions.text: A 27-year-old primigravid woman at 37 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department because of frequent contractions for 4 hours. The contractions occur every 10–15 minutes and have been increasing in intensity and duration since onset. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg. Uterine contractions are felt on palpation. Pelvic examination shows clear fluid in the vagina. The cervix is 50% effaced and 3 cm dilated. After 4 hours the cervix is 80% effaced and 6 cm dilated. Pelvic examination is inconclusive for the position of the fetal head. The fetal heart rate is reassuring. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Ultrasonography is the next best step in management for this patient whose clinical findings (regular contractions and increasing cervical effacement and dilation) indicate that she is in active labor with an unknown fetal presentation. Determining the position of the fetus is essential as abnormal fetal positioning (e.g., breech presentation) may require a cesarean delivery. Ultrasound can also detect an abnormally located placenta (e.g., placenta previa), which can also be an indication for cesarean section.

B) INCORRECT:

External cephalic version is a maneuver done in cases of breech presentation in order to maximize the chances of vaginal cephalic delivery. Because this patient presents in active labor with an unknown fetal presentation, external cephalic version is not indicated at this time. In addition, this maneuver is usually done near term but prior to labor. By the time a patient is in labor, external cephalic version is much less likely to succeed and cesarean delivery would be indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Oxytocin is used to strengthen uterine contractions when there is a prolonged latent phase of labor. This patient has been in labor for 8 hours. Since this is her first pregnancy, she would have to maintain cervical dilation < 6 cm for over 20 hours before she is considered to be in prolonged latent phase. Oxytocin is not indicated in this patient whose labor and delivery have been progressing steadily so far.

D) INCORRECT:

The Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit maneuver is used in emergent cases for management of a vaginal breech delivery. Breech presentation that cannot be corrected via external cephalic version is generally an indication for cesarean delivery. However, certain maneuvers exist to manage an unavoidable vaginal breech delivery. This maneuver is inappropriate in this patient whose fetal presentation has not been determined.

E) INCORRECT:

The nitrazine test is used for the diagnosis of premature rupture of membranes, which typically presents with significant leakage of vaginal fluid before labor onset. Because this patient has not complained of vaginal fluid leakage and is in active labor, the nitrazine test is not warranted at this time.
questions.hint: This woman has been in labor for 8 hours and is progressing with appropriate cervical dilation and effacement.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravid woman at 39 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor.
